This movie is nothing short of a dark, gritty masterpiece. I may be bias, as the Apartheid era is an area I've always felt for South Africa. The problems they have are immense due to this time in history and while many people flourish now, there is still many that lie in poverty more than 20 years after Nelson Mandela came to power. But before that can be reached this amazing film depicts what happened during that time.

This is a fine musical with a timeless score by one of my favorite composers (Gershwin) and a nice 'Parisien' atmosphere which gives the Bostonians, well Bostonians, an exotic change of scenery. Marquee lights, wine bars, haughty Americans moving around in tuxedos and Prada bags on train platforms filled me with joy. But it's the music that takes us away from this world to another place where sadness echos across the square

I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it. "Les Valseuses" was remade as the 1985's "Too Beautiful to Die" and re-made again as the 1992's American movie, Bad Love. The source film is still much more better than the previous two versions.
An airiness. Unbridled passion.
